DataElement.preferredName: Tumor Tissue Form Initial Resection Glioblastoma Diagnosis Pathologist Signed Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Indicator to signify whether or not the patient has a tumor tissue form indicating availability of archived tissue from initial resection at diagnosis of glioblastoma completed and signed by a pathologist.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Tumor Tissue Form Initial Resection Glioblastoma Diagnosis Pathologist Signed Present
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A tissue sample, or entire tumor that is removed for microscopic examination._A printed or electronic document with spaces to be filled out._Preceding all others in time or space or degree._The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ._The most malignant astrocytic tumor (WHO grade IV). It is composed of poorly differentiated neoplastic astrocytes and it is characterized by the presence of cellular polymorphism, nuclear atypia, brisk mitotic activity, vascular thrombosis, microvascular proliferation and necrosis. It typically affects adults and is preferentially located in the cerebral hemispheres. It may develop from diffuse astrocytoma WHO grade II or anaplastic astrocytoma (secondary glioblastoma), but more frequently, it manifests after a short clinical history de novo, without evidence of a less malignant precursor lesion (primary glioblastoma). Two histologic variants are recognized: giant cell glioblastoma and gliosarcoma. (WHO)_The investigation, analysis and recognition of the presence and nature of disease, condition, or injury from expressed signs and symptoms; also, the scientific determination of any kind; the concise results of such an investigation._Pathologist is a doctor specialized in medical diagnosis based on the macroscopic and microscopic study of structural changes of tissues and organs caused by the disease._Individual's name or personal mark, used to sign documents and employed to signify that the writing which precedes accords with one's wishes and intentions; an identifying feature or characteristic of something or someone; an alternative term for motif or pattern; the part of the prescription that contains directions to the patient for taking of medicine._Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A tissue sample, or entire tumor that is removed for microscopic examination.:A printed or electronic document with spaces to be filled out.

Concepts.definition: Tissue sample that contains an abnormal cellular infiltrate forming a solid mass. The abnormal cellular component can be benign or malignant. Tumor samples are obtained for microscopic examination and/or molecular analysis.
A printed or electronic document with spaces to be filled out.

Property.preferredName: First Excision Glioblastoma Diagnosis Pathologist Signature Present
Property.preferredDefinition: Preceding all others in time or space or degree.:The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ. :The most malignant astrocytic tumor (WHO grade IV). It is composed of poorly differentiated neoplastic astrocytes and it is characterized by the presence of cellular polymorphism, nuclear atypia, brisk mitotic activity, vascular thrombosis, microvascular proliferation and necrosis. It typically affects adults and is preferentially located in the cerebral hemispheres. It may develop from diffuse astrocytoma WHO grade II or anaplastic astrocytoma (secondary glioblastoma), but more frequently, it manifests after a short clinical history de novo, without evidence of a less malignant precursor lesion (primary glioblastoma). Two histologic variants are recognized: giant cell glioblastoma and gliosarcoma. (WHO) :The investigation, analysis and recognition of the presence and nature of disease, condition, or injury from expressed signs and symptoms; also, the scientific determination of any kind; the concise results of such an investigation.:Pathologist is a doctor specialized in medical diagnosis based on the macroscopic and microscopic study of structural changes of tissues and organs caused by the disease.:Individual's name or personal mark, used to sign documents and employed to signify that the writing which precedes accords with one's wishes and intentions; an identifying feature or characteristic of something or someone; an alternative term for motif or pattern; the part of the prescription that contains directions to the patient for taking of medicine.:Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.

Concepts.definition: Preceding all others in time or space or degree.
The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.

The most malignant astrocytic tumor (WHO grade 4).  It is composed of poorly differentiated neoplastic astrocytes and is characterized by the presence of cellular polymorphism, nuclear atypia, brisk mitotic activity, vascular thrombosis, microvascular proliferation, and necrosis. It typically affects adults and is preferentially located in the cerebral hemispheres. (Adapted from WHO)

The investigation, analysis and recognition of the presence and nature of disease, condition, or injury from expressed signs and symptoms; also, the scientific determination of any kind; the concise results of such an investigation.
Any physician whose career is devoted to the study of pathology.
Individual's name or personal mark, used to sign documents and employed to signify that the writing which precedes accords with one's wishes and intentions; having a handwritten signature.
Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The affirmative response to a question.

Concepts.definition: A response or indicator that can have a value of either yes or no.

ReferenceDocuments.name: Does the patient have a tumor
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does the patient have a tumor tissue form indicating availability of archived tissue from initial resection at diagnosis of glioblastoma completed and signed by a pathologist?

ReferenceDocuments.name: ABTC 1801 Text 1
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does the site agree to provide a tumor tissue form indicating availability of archived tissue from initial resection at diagnosis of glioblastoma completed and signed by a pathologist within 14 days of treatment start?

ReferenceDocuments.name: ABTC 1801 Text 3
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does the patient have a tumor tissue form indicating availability of archived tissue from a previous surgery completed and signed by a pathologist?

ReferenceDocuments.description: Does the site agree to provide a tumor tissue form indicating availability of archived tissue from initial resection at diagnosis completed and signed by a pathologist within 14 days of treatment start?

ReferenceDocuments.description: Will the patient have a tumor tissue form indicating availability of archived tissue from a previous surgery completed and signed by a pathologist within 14 days of start?
